content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice DP problem

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: After getting the hand of how to do it, it is rather easy. But you need to think quite a bit to get there, so it's probably between easy and medium.

Anyways, I had fun solving it, everything is well-explained, so I'll gladly accept it.

And if it isn't too late for suggestions, I would have liked to see both n=38 and n=37 as test cases, just for debugging reasons (to have the case of "max pins in a round <= 12").

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice follow-up to the original puzzle. Having just worked on String Balls and String Balls II, I feel like I've done a lot of dynamic programming recently, but I still stumbled around for longer than seemed necessary before I solved this puzzle. IMO, there is no such thing as too much practice with dynamic programming. Great job!

Goal section
* Suggest to include the link to the Easy edition of the puzzle: https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/count-as-i-count

Thanks.

Hello,
I hope you like this puzzle. This is the second edition of this puzzle. This one offers an introduction to dynamic programming with a simple example. Don't hesitate if you have any ideas to improve this puzzle.
The modification has been made, thank you for your help.

I was getting ready to submit my DP solution and it seemed there should be an easier way. Then I thought to try recursion. In the end, recursion was a much easier and faster solution.

Should you maybe add recursion to your tags?
